H0.text: Reducing the mass of the box would most likely require additional force to increase its speed from 1.0 m/s to 3.0 m/s within 5 s on a level surface, where a 5 N force originally achieved this.

H1.text: Increasing the mass of the box would most likely require additional force to increase the speed from 1.0 m/s to 3.0 m/s within 5 s along a level surface, where a 5 N force is originally needed.

H2.text: Making the surfaces of the box smooth would most likely require additional force to increase the speed from 1.0 m/s to 3.0 m/s within 5 s along a level surface, a task that currently requires 5 N.

H3.text: Making the surface of the floor smooth would most likely require additional force to produce the same results of increasing the speed of a box from 1.0 m/s to 3.0 m/s within 5 s along a level surface, given that a 5 N force is currently required.

A4.text: Force equals the product of the mass and the time derivative of the velocity.

A5.text: Any gain of kinetic energy, which occurs when the net force on the body accelerates it to a higher speed, must be accompanied by a loss of potential energy.
